Knowledge Point: Distributionally (i.e., syntactically) the noun functions as the head of a~noun phrase argument. Within the noun phrase, the head is placed finally, as in `man' in example (\ref{ex:4-1}), and preceding modifiers agree with the head in gender, number and case (for further details, see \chapref{chap:10}).
Content 1: \gll aní dúu dhríɡ-a \textbf{míiš-a} | \gls PROX two tall-MPL man-PL | \glt `these two tall men'

Knowledge Point: On the clause level, such a~phrase, where a~noun is the head, can serve as a~subject, as in (\ref{ex:4-2}), or a~direct object, as in (\ref{ex:4-3}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{se} \textbf{kúṛi} búd-i ki anú míi bharíiw na | \gls DEF woman understand.PFV-F COMPL PROX.MSG.NOM 1SG.GEN husband NEG | \glt `The woman understood that this wasn't her husband.'
Content 2: \gll teeṇíi čúti-m de \textbf{baṭ} uc̣h-áan-u | \gls REFL paw-PL give.CV stone pick.up-PRS"=MSG | \glt `It [the leopard] picked up a~stone with his paws.'

Knowledge Point: It can also be the head of a postpositionally marked noun phrase, as in (\ref{ex:4-4}), a noun phrase expressing location, as in (\ref{ex:4-5}), or a nominal predicate, as in (\ref{ex:4-5b}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{áa} \textbf{baṭ-á} ǰhulí dhreéɡ de | \gls IDEF stone-OBL on stretched.out be.PST | \glt `She stretched out on top of a~stone.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{hasé} \textbf{díiš-a} hateeṇ-ú ɣam bhíl-u | \gls REM village-OBL such-MSG grief become.PFV"=MSG | \glt `There was such grief in the village.'
Content 3: \gll \textbf{lhoók-u} \textbf{díiš} de | \gls small-MSG village be.PST | \glt `It was a~small village.'

Knowledge Point: A feature associated with, or assigned to, each noun is its grammatical gender. The language has two grammatical genders; each noun is either masculine, see examples in (\ref{ex:4-m}), or feminine, see examples in (\ref{ex:4-f}), following the general tradition in describing IA languages.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: While gender is an~inherent and classificatory property of the noun lexeme itself, it is essentially established through morphological agreement with adjectives/demonstratives (\ref{ex:4-6}) and verbs (\ref{ex:4-7}), for which it is a~variable property.
Content 1: \gll hasó bidráaɡ-u kuṇaák | \gls \textbf{REM.MSG.NOM} sick-\textbf{MSG} child[\textbf{M}] | \glt `that sick child'
Content 2: \gll phaí na yhéel-i | \gls girl[\textbf{F}] not come.PFV-\TEXTBF{\TEXTSC{F}} | \glt `The girl didn't come.'

Knowledge Point: There are plenty of semantic and formal clues to gender assignment in Palula. Looking again at the examples in (\ref{ex:4-m}) and (\ref{ex:4-f}), we do not have a~problem making intelligent guesses as to the gender of the words for `boy' and `older sister', respectively, if we assume that there is a~connection between biological gender or sex and this particular grammatical two"=gender differentiation between feminine nouns and masculine nouns \citep[102]{dahl2000}. Those nouns, as is the case for other nouns denoting humans and higher animates, are indeed assigned gender according to meaning~-- masculine gender if male, and feminine if female, a~phenomenon we refer to as semantic gender assignment \citep[7--32]{corbett1991}. For the word `horse, stallion', we can similarly draw the conclusion that it is a~masculine noun (especially if we are told that another word is used to refer to a~mare). The other three words, referring to either lower animates, inanimate objects or phenomena, have also~-- some way or another~-- been assigned to one of the two genders: hiimaál and phúti are feminine nouns and ɡhoóṣṭ is a~masculine noun. We cannot, however, see any obvious semantic reason for this to be so, and we will therefore have to look at other assigning criteria.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Now we will turn to formal properties that may stand in relation to gender association. First, a~comparison of a~large number of nouns reveals that particular phonological properties really seem to be related to either of the two genders. A word"=final u is for instance a~formal feature of a~major group of masculine nouns, as are á and oó for smaller groups of nouns that are all masculine (\ref{ex:4-m2}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: A word"=final unaccented i is in the same way a~feature of a~very large group of feminine nouns, and ái for a~smaller group of them (\ref{ex:4-f2}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Such nouns are usually quantified by adjectives with the meaning `much', `some', `a little', a~measuring unit or a~noun referring to some sort of container or a~quantifiable part of the whole, as in (\ref{ex:4-8}) and (\ref{ex:4-9}).
Content 1: \gll máa=the tuúš \textbf{c̣hiír} da | \gls 1SG.NOM=to some milk give.IMP.SG | \glt `Give me some milk!'
Content 2: \gll máa=the dúu ɡileesí \textbf{c̣hiír} da | \gls 1SG.NOM=to two glass.PL milk give.IMP.SG | \glt `Give me two glasses of milk!'

Knowledge Point: Only exceptionally, when speaking of more than one variety of a~substance, for instance, may a~mass noun be pluralised. Some mass nouns may also occur in a~plural form, as `blood' (\ref{ex:4-11}), as well as in a~singular form (\ref{ex:4-10}), while still being regarded as a~substance, sometimes with the connotation of large volumes or weights somehow divided up into several separate chunks or volumes. It would, however, still be ungrammatical to quantify such a~noun directly with a~numeral, whether in its singular or its plural form.
Content 1: \gll tasíi múṭii \textbf{rat-á} nikháat-a | \gls 3SG.GEN arm.GEN blood-PL appear.PFV"=MPL | \glt `Blood came from [many places of] his arm.'

Knowledge Point: While the nouns dealt with above as non"=count nouns, often referring to substances or abstract concepts, are largely limited to the singular, a~few nouns (\ref{ex:4-coll}) have a~collective meaning and occur in a~plural form only, or almost exclusively so.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: A structural property typical of proper names is that they do not normally pluralise, as they are seen as having a~unique reference, tied to one person or to one place. There is, however, no such restriction on case inflection. As proper names can take on any function in the clause, they also inflect like other nouns for case, as can be seen in (\ref{ex:4-12}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{fazelnuur-á} díi ba panǰ putr-á bhíl-a | \gls Fazal.Noor-\textbf{OBL} from TOP five son-PL become.PFV"=MPL | \glt `Fazal Noor had five sons.'

Knowledge Point: The nominative is the form of the noun used as the citation form, the subject of intransitive verbs, as in (\ref{ex:4-13}), and as the direct object, as in (\ref{ex:4-14}), of most transitive verbs. In the non"=perfective categories, it is also the case with which subjects of transitive verbs occur, as in (\ref{ex:4-14b}).
Content 1: \gll miír thaní áak \textbf{míiš} heensíl-u de | \gls Mir called one man exist.PFV"=MSG PST | \glt `There was a~man called Mir.'
Content 2: \gll haláal the \textbf{púustu} ɡhaḍ-í | \gls slaughter do.CV skin take.off-CV | \glt `After slaughtering it, he took off the skin.'
Content 3: \gll so \textbf{musaafár} šukhaáu teeṇíi huǰut-í pharé pail-óo de | \gls DEF.MSG.NOM traveller coat REFL body-OBL toward fold-3SG PST | \glt `The traveler was folding his cloak around him.'

Knowledge Point: For those nouns that take an~oblique case suffix, this is the form the noun occurs in when followed by a~postposition, as in (\ref{ex:4-15}), when serving as the agent of perfective transitive verbs, as in (\ref{ex:4-16}), and when a~noun is used as an~adverbial of time or place, as in (\ref{ex:4-17}).
Content 1: \gll teṇ-teeṇíi \textbf{ɡhooṣṭ-áam} the búi | \gls RED-REFL house-PL.OBL to go.IMP.PL | \glt `Go each to your own houses!'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{míḍ-a} maníit-u ki beedawaá na bh-úuy=a | \gls ram-OBL say.PFV"=MSG COMP impatient NEG become-IMP.PL=Q | \glt `The ram said: Let's not be impatient!'
Content 3: \gll muxáak zamanée \textbf{ɡalaṭúuk-a} ak méeš de | \gls before time.GEN Kalkatak-OBL one man be.PST | \glt `Once there was a~man in Kalkatak.'

Knowledge Point: This is also the form used for the causee in causative constructions, as in the case of `son' in (\ref{ex:4-18}).
Content 1: \gll ma teeṇíi \textbf{putr-á} čéi pila-áan-u | \gls 1SG.NOM REFL son-OBL tea give.to.drink-PRS"=MSG | \glt `I make my son drink tea.'

Knowledge Point: The genitive is used for the noun that heads a~possessive construction, see (\ref{ex:4-19})--(\ref{ex:4-20}), and for an~ablative function, either along with an~additional postposition, as in (\ref{ex:4-22}), or alone, as in (\ref{ex:4-21}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{khanɡar-íi-e} záxum lab saáz bh-áan-u | \gls sword-OBL"=GEN wound quickly whole become-PRS"=MSG | \glt `The wound of a~sword heals quickly.'
Content 2: \gll ma \textbf{šaak-úum-e} ɡhoóṣṭ saáz th-áan-u | \gls 1SG.NOM wooden-OBL.PL"=GEN house whole do-PRS"=MSG | \glt `I'm building a~wood house.'
Content 3: \gll ma \textbf{kooḍɡháii} thíi yhóol-u | \gls 1SG.NOM Kotgha.GEN from come.PFV"=MSG | \glt `I came from Kotgha.'
Content 4: \gll ma \textbf{c̣hetrúul-e} wh-áand-u | \gls 1SG.NOM Chitral-GEN come.down-PRS"=MSG | \glt `I'm coming [down] from Chitral.'

Knowledge Point: The genitive is also used for the object in constructions with the verb ǰe- `hit', see (\ref{ex:4-23}). The background of this special case may possibly be explained (as \citealt[43]{baart1999a}, has done for Kohistani Gawri) with an~implicit object with the nominal meaning `hit'.
Content 1: \gll ma paalaá ɡhin-í \textbf{phút-am-e} ǰ-áan-u | \gls 1SG.NOM leaf take-CV fly-OBL.PL"=GEN hit-PRS"=MSG | \glt `I'm driving away flies with leaves.'

Knowledge Point: One of the expressions of an instrumental function, or possibly case, is (as far as I have evidence) formally identical to the oblique plural and occurs in the form of `gun' in example (\ref{ex:4-24}), regardless of number reference.
Content 1: \gll se míiš-a ba huṇḍíi thíi se bhalá-ii \textbf{toobak-íim} ǰít-i | \gls DEF man-OBL TOP from.above from DEF spirit-GEN gun-INS hit.PFV-F | \glt `The man shot from above with his gun at the spirit.'

Knowledge Point: This example of case syncretism is in itself a~hint that the origin of the ergative marking is in the instrumental. However, instrumentality is also, and more frequently, expressed with a~converb (see \sectref{subsec:13-4-1}), such as ɡhiní from ɡhin- `take' (as in example (\ref{ex:4-23}) above).
Content 1: \gll ma paalaá ɡhin-í \textbf{phút-am-e} ǰ-áan-u | \gls 1SG.NOM leaf take-CV fly-OBL.PL"=GEN hit-PRS"=MSG | \glt `I'm driving away flies with leaves.'

Knowledge Point: Unique vocative forms (whether we regard it as a~case or not) of nouns only occur with some kinship terms, as in (\ref{ex:4-25})--(\ref{ex:4-26}). These forms are shorter than the corresponding nominative forms, appearing without their ``gender signaling'' u- or i-endings.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{phéep} séer-i=ee | \gls father's.sister.VOC fine-F=Q | \glt `How are you auntie [politely addressing any middle"=aged woman]?'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{dóod} sóor-u=ee | \gls father's.father.VOC fine-MSG=Q | \gls \glt `How are you grandpa [politely addressing any aged man]?'

Knowledge Point: especially true of the postposition wée `in, into', as can be seen in (\ref{ex:4-27}),
Content 1: \gll so \textbf{meedóon"=ee} (=meedóon-a wée) nikháat-u | \gls he field-``LOCATIVE'' [=field-OBL in] appear.PFV"=MSG | \glt `He appeared in the field.'

Knowledge Point: would like to suggest the diachronic developments (partly based on \citealt{turner1966}) in (\ref{ex:4-ety1}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Also a~few nouns of the OIA declension with stems ending in a~consonant have ended up here, particularly neuters with a~final n in their stems. Some examples are shown in (\ref{ex:4-ety2}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: With a~rather high level of confidence we can trace this Palula accent shift to an~originally stressed (or accented) root final -á (found among OIA nouns with a~stem ending in a), which was deleted through apocope some time between MIA \citep[247--248]{pischel2011} and the emergence of a~Palula proto"=language (in proto"=Shina or at an~even earlier stage), leaving the last remaining vocalic mora of the noun in the nominative singular with the accent, while preserving it on the original segment in the inflected noun forms, as in the OIA \textit{dev\'{\={a}}s, dev\'{\={a}}n, dev\'{\={a}}nām}, the nominative, accusative and genitive plural forms of devá `god' respectively \citep[330]{whitney1960}. The proposed diachronic developments are shown in (\ref{ex:4-ety3}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: \citet[15]{morgenstierne1941}, as well as \citet[29]{buddruss1967}, suggests the OIA derivation -aka- (also belonging to the large a-ending declension in OIA) as the origin of these typically masculine endings. According to \citet[222]{masica1991}, this -aka- (in the nominative singular -akas) has been subject to weakening via \textit{-akō {\textgreater} -aɡō {\textgreater} -ahu {\textgreater} -au}, ending up as -ō or \textit{-\={a}} in many NIA languages. That may be so, but I also hold it for very likely that this rather major group of masculine nouns has been further expanded through analogy with the aka-derived nouns, some of them possibly with an~adjectival origin. In any case, for a~few Palula nouns with an~ending u there is indeed evidence of OIA cognates (or established reconstructions) with -aka- (or -uka) formation, see (\ref{ex:4-ety4}), although it will be necessary to posit a~stress or accent"=shift (due to reasons I am not able to formulate now) to have taken place for those words that were stressed on the final syllable in OIA.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The nouns for which I have been able to trace an~OIA cognate and also am able to hypothesise on their development into the Palula form, as shown in (\ref{ex:4-ety5}), are either from the OIA declension with stems ending in a~short vowel i or u, the declension with stems ending in a~long vowel ā, ī, ũ, or are derived nouns in OIA, ending in -ya.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The development of this declension is to some extent a~feminine parallel to that of the masculine u-ending nouns of the a-declension. A feminine derivational suffix -ikā- was used in OIA in much the same way as the above"=mentioned -aka- \citep[1222]{whitney1960}, while the NIA endings with their origin in -ikā- probably retain much more of the Sanskritic diminutive sense \citep[222]{masica1991}. OIA nouns with the ending -ikā- are part of the OIA declension 3 together with other nouns ending in a~long vowel. Some examples of Palula m-declension nouns with probable OIA ikā-cognates are displayed in (\ref{ex:4-ety6}).
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: This group is closely related to the u-ending nouns of the a-declension (in the closely related variety spoken in Sau, Afghanistan, these two build up a~declension of their own vis-à-vis the other nouns in the a-declension). Like those, the oo-ending nouns derive from the OIA declension of a-ending nouns, as shown in (\ref{ex:4-ety7}).
Content 1: Not found
